page.title: 12THE GROUNDS OF HONING HALL
page.content: On April 23rd.1985 we tourwd the grounds of Honing Hall. The park is surrounded by a belt of mixed woodland, with individual trees such as oaks and cedars dotted about the pasture. The park is divided into sections by electric fencing so that grazing cattle may be controlled. The old kitchen garden still survives, but the brickwork of the walls and buildings shows signs of neglect.Only part of the garden is used for vegetable growing. The remainder is overgrown, but may be used eventually for a tennis court. Other outbuildings are in a good state of repair - the stables with the groom's house and carriage shed attached, the estate office, and the carpenters shop, the latter being the only building still in regular use. A large clock dominates the stable courtyard.
